dialogue: Obviously, sea creatures eat other creatures.
Bigger animals eat smaller ones, simple!
But where does the energy come from?
Well, the food chain can explain that!
The food chain is made up of several "trophic" levels.
Organisms in the first trophic level are known as the producers.
Producers are organisms that produce their own energy with sunlight, or other methods.
In the ocean, the main producers are creatures called phytoplankton.
Organisms like zooplankton, algae or small fish eat the phytoplankton directly, and are known as primary consumers
These are what make up the second trophic level.
Going up one more trophic level to the secondary consumers...
Creatures like jellyfish, squid and larger fish eat the primary consumers!
How does plastic play into all of this, though?
The producers will naturally ingest the microplastics that are around them.
Then, when the primary consumers eat the producers, they absorb the microplastics that the producers had in their bodies.
Then, the secondary consumers will eat the primary consumers, and absorb the microplastics from the primary consumers AND the producers.
Bigger creatures will keep absorbing the plastic from smaller creatures, and so on and so on.
This is why creatures higher up will on average have more microplastics, even though they live in comparatively less polluted areas.
